animalOfTheDay.name: wild boar
facts: Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They have an excellent sense of smell.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.
They are social animals and live in large herds.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.

randomAnimals.name: tuna
facts: Tuna are among the fastest fish, reaching speeds up to 47 mph.
They have a unique circulatory system that conserves heat in their muscles.
They are warm-blooded, unlike most fish, which helps them swim in cold waters.
Tuna can migrate across entire oceans, traveling thousands of miles.

randomAnimals.name: lamb
facts: They can stand and walk within an hour of being born.
Lambs are born with a full set of milk teeth that are replaced by adult teeth as they grow.
They form strong social bonds and can become stressed when separated from their flock.
Lambs can recognize their mother's voice within a few hours of being born.

randomAnimals.name: newfoundland
facts: No facts available.
